intro: Cassine lanceolata, commonly known as the narrow-leaved cassine, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its lance-shaped leaves and showy, pink or white flowers that bloom in summer. It typically grows in wetlands and along stream banks, thriving in moist, sandy soils. Cassine lanceolata is often used in wetland restoration projects due to its ecological importance and adaptability.
